item.title: What comes after ‘seeing is believing’
item.description: In the age of AI, photographs no longer express truth. That doesn’t make them any less meaningful.

item.title: Trump tests a cunning workaround on executive power
item.description: Does using force outside U.S. borders legitimize claiming emergency power within them?

item.title: North Korea is a nuclear power. Trump’s omission is an admission.
item.description: It’s time to start talking realistically about limiting the size and range of Pyongyang’s arsenal.

item.title: Law and order is a two-way street
item.description: Sanctuary policies create an easy excuse for ICE to go into communities.

item.title: The Gaza peace deal risks being buried in the sands of mistrust
item.description: So long as Hamas refuses to disarm, Israel cannot withdraw.

item.title: The gaping hole in the transgender sports case
item.description: Avoiding the definition of a woman is hurting the trans rights movement.

item.title: Federal agencies drown Americans with unreleased regulatory ‘guidance’
item.description: The Good Act is a good act.

item.title: The real reason people move to red states
item.description: Housing, money and the cure to loneliness, in readers’ eyes.

item.title: Spanberger’s opportunity
item.description: Virginians yearn for competent leadership, not radical change.

item.title: Trump’s Fed lawfare backfired quickly
item.description: Markets price in higher rates as the president suggests he won’t nominate Kevin Hassett for chair.

item.title: Attacks on the press? America’s seen this before.
item.description: A history of government vs. the media, from the Pentagon Papers to Obama.

item.title: Menopause isn’t a disease
item.description: Aging, fertility, Iran and refugees, through readers’ eyes.

item.title: Yulia Navalnaya: Dictators are coming for the lawyers
item.description: The persecution of my husband’s lawyers shows how authoritarian power eliminates dissent at its source.
